data.title: add viewlets to View menu
vscode reports warning on constructor guards
malfunction entering rgb code in css file
data.body:
I was trying to replace one rgb value with another, and VSC 0.10.6 just would not let me key #1493C9.  First the number keys above my keyboard would not enter input.  I used the keypad to right and got everything in until I got to C and Intellisense was presenting to me colors that were already in the file.

I had to paste the value in to get my editing done.

data.title: C# project has unusably slow intellisense
data.body:
Hi, on recent versions of Code (.10.6 and I believe a few versions before) I've been having terrible problems with completion on a C# project.  Intellisense completion will work fine for a little bit, then start coming up extremely slowly, and then will not come up at all.  Error checking is also extremely lagged.  After a little bit it will start working again.  It seems like Ominsharp is completely dying and restarting in the background.  It feels like switching files will cause it to happen more often.  It's not something that resetting Code seems to help with, and happens at least every minute so Code is completely unusable on this project.  Any help would be super appreciated!

This is on Mac OS 10.11.1 using a rather large Unity project.

Here is a zipped MOV file of the issue, it starts really breaking at around 1 minute mark.
[SlowdownBug.mov.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/86369/SlowdownBug.mov.zip)

Here is my output log:

data.title: AutoHotkey (Windows)/Keyboard Maestro (OS X) text replacements don't work in Visual Studio Code
data.body:
I have the exact same issue with AutoHotkey in Windows and Keyboard Maestro in OS X:

I have a setup where **btw** is automatically replaced with **by the way**.

In every application I have tested, except VSCode, this works. Every time I type **btw**, these three characters are deleted and **by the way** inserted instead. In VSCode the three characters are deleted, but **by the way** is never inserted.

I'm no expert on text replacement apps, but I think the text replacements apps work by simulating three presses on the backspace key, then simulating a press on each character key in **by the way** or by adding **by the way** to the clipboard and then pasting it into the active window.

If you want to recreate the bug, try the following AutoHotkey file:

```
:?*:btw::by the way
```

data.title: Gulp tasks are listed in duplicate

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
According to the docs ["Autodetecting Gulp, Grunt and Jake Tasks"](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/tasks#_autodetecting-gulp-grunt-and-jake-tasks), **`gulpfile.js` at project root** is loaded and tasks in that are listed automatically.

`gulpfile.js`:

``` js
var gulp = require('gulp');
gulp.task('gulpfileTASK1', function() {});
gulp.task('gulpfileTASK2', function() {});
gulp.task('gulpfileTASK3', function() {});
```

VS Code Command `>Tasks: Run Task`:

```
gulpfileTASK1
gulpfileTASK2
gulpfileTASK3
```

This autodetecting is disabled (`gulpfile.js` is ignored) if tasks are defined in `.vscode/tasks.json`, right?

`tasks.json`:

``` json
{
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "command": "something",
  "isShellCommand": true,
  "tasks": [
    {
      "taskName": "tasksjsonTASK1",
      "args": []
    },
    {
      "taskName": "tasksjsonTASK2",
      "args": []
    },
    {
      "taskName": "tasksjsonTASK3",
      "args": []
    }
  ]
}
```

VS Code Command `>Tasks: Run Task` (tasks in `gulpfile.js` are not listed):

```
tasksjsonTASK1
tasksjsonTASK2
tasksjsonTASK3
```

It seems that behavior above is right.
But if `gulp` is specified to the `command` above (`"command": "gulp"`), tasks in both files are listed.

VS Code Command `>Tasks: Run Task`:

```
gulpfileTASK1
gulpfileTASK2
gulpfileTASK3
tasksjsonTASK1
tasksjsonTASK2
tasksjsonTASK3
```

Of course the tasks in `tasks.json` are gulp tasks because `command` is `gulp`. `gulpfileTASK*` tasks should not be listed.

When `--gulpfile` is specified, these tasks are listed even if `gulpfile.js` is another named and it is in outside of project root.

`tasks.json`:

``` json
{
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "command": "gulp",
  "isShellCommand": true,
  "args": [
    "--gulpfile", "PATH/TO/OUTSIDE/OF/PROJECT/ANOTHER_NAME.js"
  ],
  "tasks": [
    {
      "taskName": "tasksjsonTASK1",
      "args": []
    },
    {
      "taskName": "tasksjsonTASK2",
      "args": []
    },
    {
      "taskName": "tasksjsonTASK3",
      "args": []
    }
  ]
}
```

VS Code Command `>Tasks: Run Task`:

```
gulpfileTASK1
gulpfileTASK2
gulpfileTASK3
tasksjsonTASK1
tasksjsonTASK2
tasksjsonTASK3
```

It seems that the autodetecting is enabled always when `command` is `gulp` even if there is not `gulpfile.js` at project root.

data.title: Sass/Scss - Issue with the Sass map and @each rule
IntelliSense filtering has become slow again in huge lists
data.body:
Copied from the inital issue (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extensionbuilders/issues/80)

> Let's see this scenario:
> - The cursor is placed on whitespace inside a method
> - The user asks for completions by pressing `CTRL + Space`
> - The language service is being asked to provide all suggestions
> - The suggestion box pops up containing all 20k symbols
> - The user types the character `f`
> - **VSCode hangs for ~8 seconds** until the letter is displayed and the suggestion box shows only suggestions containing an `f`. (VSCode doesn't ask for suggestions twice. All the time is spent outside the language service. )
> - typing the next letter is being processed faster but it's still slow. 

@joaomoreno fixed this issue on 2015-11-06 telling that there were too many event listeners. With the December update it has become slow again. VSCode hangs now for **~10 seconds** working on the same suggestion list. 
I really hope it's going to be fast again with the January update. It's not funny to work in huge projects now.

data.title: VSCodeDebugProtocol returns lowercase breakpoint paths
data.body:
VSCode 0.10.6 on Mac OSX 10.11.1
Using [vscode-php-debug](https://github.com/felixfbecker/vscode-php-debug) (XDebug adapter for PHP debugging)

---

`VSCodeDebugProtocol.SetBreakpointsArguments()` returns lowercase paths for breakpoints. 

XDebug expects to see a path like `/Developer/Project/file.php` but we're setting a breakpoint for `/developer/project/file.php`. This has allegedly been [resolved with an option in XDebug 2.3](http://bugs.xdebug.org/view.php?id=973) but as per the nature of that release, developers working on PHP <= 5.3 projects do not benefit from that fix.

I made a [proof of concept change](https://github.com/AndrewNatoli/vscode-php-debug/commit/d0c7569e5d9c12830ab9f9e0fc499b944ec1415e) that replaces the lowercase path returned by `VSCodeDebugProtocol.SetBreakpointsArguments()` with the actual `cwd` and it resolved the issue. Alas, if it's possible without having adverse effects elsewhere, it would make sense to return the correct path to begin with instead of needing each adapter to program around this. 

Original report: https://github.com/felixfbecker/vscode-php-debug/issues/8

data.title: tasks.json support buggy?
data.body:
I have the tasks.json file below.  I wish there was an integrated deploy task, and that we could natively have multiple top-level tasks defined that each can have their own command but according to various posts out there, we cannot and this kind of workaround is recommended.  But it isn't working for me.  

You can see that I'm asking to show the output, but when I run the build task via the keyboard shortcut or the <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd> menu, the spinner spins, the first command seems to get run (because I can see the output files get created) but the second doesn't run and doesn't generate any output to the output pane which VSCode makes visible.  The third never runs either.  If I move the `echo 42` to the first position then I'll see 42 in the output window _sometimes_ but it is inconsistent.  If `echo 42` is first and `tsc` is second, tsc does not get run.  The deploy.sh does generate output when run in the terminal, but even if it is first, it doesn't get run or generate output 

Also sometimes, the busy spinner in the bottom left corner gets stuck in the spinning mode, but the "Terminate Running Task" does nothing to fix it.  I don't know if this is a task that is really still running, or just a UI that falls out of sync.  Restarting VSCode fixes it.

I even tried wrapping the args like `"args": ["\"echo 42\""]` because in the terminal `bash -c "echo 42"` and `bash -c ".\Deploy.sh"` work fine.  This seems to have no effect sometimes but other times I get "bash: echo 42: command not found" in the output pane.  I suspect there's some kind of delay in refreshing the tasks.json contents into VSCode's memory or something but I haven't really figured it out - I'm mostly just baffled.

``` json
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "bash",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "args": [ "-c" ],
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "Typescript Compile",
            "suppressTaskName": true,
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "args": ["tsc"],
            "problemMatcher": "$tsc",
            "showOutput": "always"
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Deploy",
            "suppressTaskName": true,
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "showOutput": "always",
            "args": ["${workspaceRoot}/Deploy.sh"]
        },
        {
            "taskName": "Done",
            "suppressTaskName": true,
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "showOutput": "always",
            "args": ["echo 42"]
        } ]
}
```

data.title: Tabs in editor not work
data.body: The editor does not work tab, open only one tab

data.title: Erasing should erase with tab size

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
If there are no characters between the caret and column 0 in the current line. Hitting the erase keyboard button should erase the amount of columns of the defined tab size and not 1 column.

``` typescript
class A {
        | // if press erase here
-----------------------------------
    | // the caret should land here
}
```

data.title: CTRL+S is slow

data.body: Saving file by pressing CTRL+S (and, of course by saving it through the menu) makes VS Code freeze for about a second
